Award.AwardTitle: A facile pretreatment strategy for recovering sugars and lignin effectively from a variety of lignocellulosic feedstocks

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0933250
Varanasi

Summary

Intellectual Merits: Plant biomass can provide a sustainable feedstock for future "biorefineries" partially replacing conventional petrochemical refineries. The PI plans to capitalize on the solvation properties of ionic liquids (ILs) to overcome the recalcitrance of cellulose and biomass to enzymatic hydrolysis, a core barrier to economical and sustainable biofuels production. The hydrolyzate can be used as a fermentation feedstock for ethanol production or as a sugar platform for production of other chemicals. With the proper selection of enzymes, initial rates of hydrolysis for IL treated pure cellulose are nearly 2 orders of magnitude greater than those of untreated cellulose. Conversion of cellulose in biomass is also substantially accelerated in comparison to alternative pretreatment methods. The proposed research seeks to systemically assess and optimize the pretreatment process applied to biomass with the aim of minimizing chemical and energy inputs. To achieve this, a clear understanding of the structural and chemical changes in biomass with ionic liquid pretreatment and the effects of those changes on subsequent hydrolysis is needed. The following specific objectives will be addressed to achieve this end:(1) Assess fundamental factors which affect kinetics and product yield for biomass saccharification to optimize pretreatment. (2) Engineer the hydrolyzing enzyme mixture to optimize hexose and pentose sugar yields from IL-pretreated biomass. (3) Recover and recycle saccharification enzymes and ionic liquids and assess unhydrolyzed portions of biomass for lignin recovery.

Broader impacts: Ionic liquids have the potential to convert wood and grasses into viable feedstocks for fuel and chemical production. Ionic liquids have no measurable vapor pressure and are considered green due to their negligible impact on air quality. An essential part of this project is the training and educating of graduate and undergraduate students, who will obtain considerable experience in biochemical methods, analytical techniques, ionic liquid synthesis, characterization, and assessment of chemical and structural changes in lignocellulosic materials, a very complex system. The interdisciplinary nature of this project will allow graduate and undergraduate researchers to acquire a broad-based training. Demonstration modules and background material will be developed in biofuels for integration into UTube, a site spear-headed by our collaborator Dr. Jared Anderson. The site will contain links to a series of video demonstrations performed by the co-investigators and undergraduate researchers tailored to middle school children. The PI and Co-PI's have served as high school and undergraduate student research mentors. One has participated in the NSF Young Scholars program, to introduce economically disadvantaged students to engineering. The other has been involved in outreach activities as the faculty advisor to the Society of Woman Engineers and through involvement in the GEARUP and EXCEL programs sponsored by the US Department of Education to introduce African American and Latino middle and high school students to hands-on engineering projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

In an economy based on renewable resources, plant biomass can provide a sustainable feedstock for future “biorefineries” partially replacing conventional petrochemical refineries. In this project we have capitalized on the solvation properties of ionic liquids (ILs) to overcome the recalcitrance of cellulose and biomass to enzymatic hydrolysis, a core barrier to economical and sustainable biofuels production. The hydrolyzate can be used as a fermentation feedstock for ethanol production or as a sugar platform for production of other chemicals. The micro and macro-crystalline structure of cellulose is converted to an amorphous structure through pretreatment with IL. Also, through IL-pretreatment, the Lignin-carbohydrate bonds appear to be severed to the extent necessary to provide access to cellulases, while leaving lignin structure in tact. Conversion of cellulose in biomass is also substantially accelerated in comparison to alternative pretreatment methods. This research project systemically assessed and optimized the pretreatment process with the aim of minimizing chemical and energy inputs. Towards this goal, the structural and chemical changes in biomass with ionic liquid pretreatment and the effects of those changes on subsequent hydrolysis were studied. Specifically, we 1) addressed the fundamental factors which affect kinetics and product yield for biomass saccharification during IL pretreatment. (2) engineered the hydrolyzing enzyme mixture to optimize hexose and pentose sugar yields following IL-pretreatment, and (3) recovered and recycled the IL and lignin after pretreatment and saccharification.

 Broader impacts

 The potential impact of this research is immense. Ionic liquids have the potential to convert wood and grasses into viable feedstocks for fuel and chemical production in the same way that corn is now being used to produce ethanol. Ionic liquids possess unique physical and chemical properties: these liquid salts have no measurable vapor pressure and are considered green due to their negligible impact on air quality compared to many conventional solvents. The hydrophilic ILs effective in biomass pretreatment appear to have little potential to bio-accumulate in aquatic biota. The ability of ILs to penetrate and produce structural and/or chemical changes in biomass provides a facile and efficient route for enzymatic (or chemical means of) saccharification and in-tact lignin recovery. Because of the more open structure of IL treated biomass, energy and chemical inputs are minimized.

Research results were widely disseminated through conference presentations and journal publications. An essential part of this project was the training and education of graduate and undergraduate students. The interdisciplinary nature of this project allowed graduate and undergraduate researchers to acquire a broad-based training: the participating students obtained valuable experience in biochemical methods, analytical techniques, ionic liquid synthesis, characterization, and assessment of chemical and structural changes in lignocellulosic materials, a very complex system. The PI and Co-I also served as high school and undergraduate student research mentors.

The investigators made a number of presentations to local schools, television and news-paper media to inform and educate K-12 students and teachers as well as the public at-large on the impact and role of renewable fuels and chemicals on our every-day life, environment, and “energy-independence” of the nation.
